abstract.p: Emmy Awards broadcast on Sept 10 is seen by 21.8 million viewers and is most-watched Emmy Awards show since Nielsen company started using people-meter ratings system in 1986 (S)

block.p: The Emmy Awards struck back this week against all those who have denigrated the award as all but meaningless: with 21.8 million viewers, the broadcast Sunday on ABC was the most-watched Emmy Awards show since the Nielsen company started using the people-meter ratings system in 1986.

The Emmy Awards struck back this week against all those who have denigrated the award as all but meaningless: with 21.8 million viewers, the broadcast Sunday on ABC was the most-watched Emmy Awards show since the Nielsen company started using the people-meter ratings system in 1986.
The show also added significant numbers of younger viewers, bringing in the most young adult women since 1994 and the most young adult men since 1992.
Many television executives said that the big increase in ratings was proof that television was having a revival of sorts with the American public.
Naturally the biggest evidence of that revival has been the enormous number of people watching first ''Who Wants to be A Millionaire'' on ABC and then ''Survivor'' on CBS.
But neither show was up for any Emmy Awards, though the show did open with an elaborate comedy sketch based on ''Survivor.''

One difference this year was a change in the voting system, which broke away from the blue-ribbon panels that previously selected winners after watching nominees over one day in one room. This year the winners were picked by a much broader group of voters who watched tapes at home.
The most noticeable result was more Emmys for the shows considered the hottest favorites of the season: five for ''The West Wing'' and three for ''Will and Grace.''
